sp.l: That as he run from Spayne, he shall run hence,
Or I shall make him a poore Emperour.
His Bastard brauery tell him must goe downe,
And the legitimate weare Caesars Crowne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fayle not to vtter euery sillable
Both of the Palsgraues sending and our owne.

sp.speaker: Cul.
sp.l: I shall deliuer both.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: Tak't how they please,
If they fly hence, weele follow through the Seas.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.l: I goe. Exit Cullen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: High is this Embassy, like to your valour,
Which I admire, and loue ardently;
That I could wish your presence all my dayes,
And thinke your company to me more sweete
Then mine owne Kingdome, or my Crowne besides.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: Your loue and Royall presence I desire.

sp.speaker: K. Clynton,
sp.l: and bold Fytzwaters, be it your charge,
Prouided well of our best ships and Souldiers,
To sayle to Germanie, and free our friends,
Kept as we heare there with a slender guard,
In a weake Castle.

sp.speaker: Old Fitz.
sp.l: Which weele soone beats downe.

sp.speaker: Passgr.
sp.l: And bring them hither.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p: Or returne no more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: March forwards to the place where weel encampe

div.stage: Enter Fitz-waters, Artoyse, Vandome, and Mendoza.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: What should the reason be of this dissention
And why is young Fitz-waters froward thus?

sp.speaker: Artoyse.
sp.l: His arguments are strong and forcible.

sp.speaker: Mendoz.
sp.l: Single vs hither to the forrest side,
Vnder pretense to plot more priuately,
And now not onely to mislike! our drifts,
But call vs punies, and vnskilfull men,
If showes a spleenefull hatred to vs all.

sp.speaker: Y. Frytz.
sp.l: Not vnto all, but only to you two:
Why should the Earle and I borne a Lords sonne,
Ioine with a paire of base companions,
In such a waighty cause as a Kings death:
I know youle say you haue beene physitians,
Sailer, and Soldiers, and in such disguise,
Done some exploit that haue deserv'd respect,
I graunt as much, but yet your birthes are meane.
No gentry in your blood was ever knowne
By naturall Heraldry, your low discents
Disables vs, and we must seeke to rise,
With others of our own condition.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Come Vandome, of our selues weele do the deed

sp.speaker: Y. Fitz.
sp.l: That were the ingrossing of the same from vs
And so you would haue all the thankes your selues:
Neither commixt with vs, nor yet alone,
Shall it be acted, but as we are the best
In brith, and ability to doe it,
Weele haue the priuiledge of doing it:

sp.speaker: Vandome.
sp.l: And we should giue it ouer.

sp.speaker: Y. Fitz.
sp.l: To your betters.
Or having fit place, Artoise and my selfe,
Will kill you first, then cast you in the River.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.l: Hee speakes what wee intend.

sp.speaker: Mendozze.
sp.l: Intend your worse?
Caesar has promisde him the Palsgraues place,
And I shall be the Marquesse Brandenburgh:
Thinke you such Titles shalbe lost by feare.
Our valour has bene tryde with worthy men,
And ere we loose the glorie of the Act,
Vandome and I doe meane to vse you so.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.l: Theyle nere be honest.

sp.speaker: Vandome.
sp.l: Come Syr, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.l: Most resolute villains, how they would out-braue vs?

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.l: But noble Artoise, now the fire is giuen
The Cannon must goe off.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.l: Vnto theyr deaths.
sp.stage: Fight. Y. Fyth and Artoise kill Vandoume, and Mendozza.
sp.l: So they are dead, and now the Fame remaines
Onely to vs, that will accomplish it.

sp.speaker: Y. Ftyh.
sp.l: Onely to mee, that will perform't alone.
Thinkes Artoise those were slaine cause they are base?
Or that I wrought you to assist my plot,
Because you are of the Nobilitie?
No, I haue still this Maxime in my thoughts,
That a Competitor, though nere so Noble,
Takes away halfe the same in euery thing:
I could haue opend this vnto you all,
But that I thought my selfe too weake for three:
And therefore prouidently vsde thy strength,
To kill them first, that I might slay thee after.
Now they are dead, thy life must follow theirs,
And so I share the honour to my selfe:
I will be Palsgraue, Marquesse Brandenburgh,
And the Bohemian King in mee alone,
Caesar shall write himselfe three Friends in one.

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.l: I doe not think thou meanst to be a traitor.

sp.speaker: Y. Fitz.
sp.l: Now you come neer me, but that secrets mine,
And seeking it you must digge through my heart,
Or it will nere be found, it lyes so close.

sp.speaker: Art:
sp.l: Ile know it, or a reason in your blood.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz:
sp.l: Wilt thou turne honest?

sp.speaker: Artoise.
sp.l: Doe not torture mee,
With repetition of that Beggars name:
Whome none but Idiots, Innocents, or blockes
Will entertaine.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.l: I would change your minde
From this erronious and ill boding thought,
Because of late you freed me from the rocke,
But if it be so hurtfull to your sight
Be your own death, Ile not reueale my minde.

sp.speaker: Arto.
sp.l: If that I cannot force it with my sworde,
Ile let it alone.
So lye together, three a paire Royall makes,
And heres a paire Royall of excellent Villaines;
These haue slaine princes by their owne confession,
These made a Nation swimme in her owne blood,
The streame is turnde with you, t'is now high flood:
But I must cast you all into the Riuer.
Yea, swords and all, to cleare mee from suspect;
Suspect? by whome this place yeelds no such eye,
Tis well the worlds rid of their villanie. Exit.

div.stage: Enter seuerally, the French king and Floramell.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.l: His Highnes here, then Floramell giue back.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: Tis shee, a word; theres no retiring hence.
In vaine you striue, my force opposde against yours,
Will easily subdue your womans strength,
But theres a power included in your eye
That conquers Kings, subdues a Deitie.
And he that had the strength to rule those graces,
Might nere be caught, yet view the brightest faces:
One kisse, and Ile no more importune you.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: On that condition, I will graunt you one.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: But you must giue it mee.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: Dian forbid, that were immodestie.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: It must be so.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.l: Vpon your Kingly Oath,
Neuer hereafter to renew your sute.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: Now by my crowne I sweare.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: Take it.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: Tis done:
And with this kisse, a second Fire begun,
More ardent are my thoughts now then before:
I lou'd thee well, but now I loue thee more.
Thou shalt not leaue me, but for euer dwell,
Where I abide, thy absence is my hell.

sp.speaker: Floram.
sp.p: Thinke on your Oath.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: At Louers periurie, the Gods themselues doe winke.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: A king say so, pardon me sir, your wil Ile not obey.
But your oth broken mainely run a away. Exit Floram.

div.stage: Enter the Queene, hauing heard their conference.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: So, so, so: This is the affection that you beare to me?
Thinkes the French King Ile not reuenge this wrong?
As I am Queene of France, Ile make her know,
What tis to be corriuall in my Loue:
Shee dyes by Heauen.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: If thou but spoyle a haire,
Or shed one drop of her celestiall blood
For any courtesie I haue offered her,
My wrath shall: as a furie haunt the deed.
And Ile torment thee for such crueltie,
Worse then the damned in the world below.
I seldome threaten, but I doe it straight,
Her death thy Hell, looke too't, tis a shrewd fate.

sp.speaker: F. Queene.
sp.l: Hee euer yet was soueraigne of his word,
What shall I doe, brooke this corriualship?
No, since I cannot in the Realme of France,
Haue the reuenge my longing heart desires,
Else-where Ile seeke it, I of late behold
An English Lord in fauour at the Court,
His Name Fitzwaters, and I loue him well:
By his procurement I will lay a plot,
To yeeld King Iohn vnto his enemies,
So to obtaine my purpose, if it take
How euer Fooles may thinke to proiect ill,
It likes mee well, because I haue my will.

div.stage: Enter a Frenchman and an Englishman.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: An Englishman & a traueller; what are you?

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: A Frenchman, and no traueller.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: Then giue way; For I am the better man.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: The better man?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: I, the better man, by the porambulation of 2. or 3. thousand miles, I haue seene the great Turke borrow Money, and neuer minde the repayment ont.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: Peuh, is that all? we haue a number of great Christians that will doe so, and when a man comes to demaund his owne somewhat boldly, hee shalbe committed to prison, or made a Foole, to stand wayting at the foredore where the Coach stands, whiles the Lord steales out at the backe-dore by water.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: Ist possible?

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: That our Tradesmen can tell, to their great hindrance, & I my selfe know this, that being in pouertie, a Lord calld me by my name thrice, but hee would not remember it once, when hee came to his Lands.

sp.speaker: Englishman.
sp.p: The reason is, least thou shouldst begge some of his New-liuing.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: Nay rather for feare of paying the old score.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: Sure thou art some Noblemans bastard, thou canst tell their tricks so right.

sp.speaker: French.
sp.p: And by some great woman: For I can tell you their trickes too.

sp.speaker: English.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: French.
sp.p: Your only fine Lady is wantonnesse, & new Fashions, your Cittizens wife gallops after. But shee is not so well horste to ouertake her.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: Now wee are in the discourse of women, What Countrey-women doest thou loue best?

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: I loue none.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: I loue all, and to kisse them after the fashion of all Nations.

sp.speaker: Frenchm.
sp.p: Why I pray sir, doe not all Nations kisse alike?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: You are no Traueller, and therfore Ile beare with your ignorance: but know this, your Spanyard, as hee is prowde, hee kisses prowdly, as if hee scornde the touch of a Ladies lippe; marry you Frenchmen draw it in, as if hee would swallow her aliue: Now the Italian has soone done with the vpper parts, to be tickling of the lower: and we Englishmen can neuer take enough at both endes.

sp.speaker: Frenchm:
sp.p: Is not your name Maister doe much?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: It is, and yours (I thinke should be Monsieur doe litle.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Wee ere somewhat a kinne in the first part of our names, and I pray heartily let vs be better acquainted together.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.p: You must doe as I doe then, and since we were both appointed, to wayte heere for the French Queenes comming, lets take her golde, and forsweare our selues.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.p: Heere comes her Maiestie.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p:
Are you resolu'de to vndergoe this charge? Tis but an Oath, which I will guild with Crownes,
And beare you out against the Law.

sp.speaker: Frenchm.
sp.p: I can doe little beeing so animated, if I should not forsweare my selfe, for so fayre a Queene.

sp.speaker: Englishm:
sp.p: And Ile doe as much as your Maiestie will haue me doe.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: Take this in earnest, and when tis done, you shall haue more.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Wee will.

sp.speaker: Englishman.
sp.p: And from this time forwards, let vs bee forsworne brothers.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.l: Content. Exeunt French. & English.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Ile instruct you: Here comes Fitzwaters.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.l: According to your Maiesties commaund,
I come to know your pleasure for the Letter
I should deliuer to the English King,
With that base strumpet that has Iniur'd you.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: There is the Letter, which I charge you beare vnto King Edward, and assure his Grace I will performe what I haue promis'de in't, Ile send the strumpet to you instantly. Exit Queene.

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.l: I knowe not by what influence I am falne
Into the affection of this potent Queene:
But shee has sworne shee loues me as her soule:
And to enioy me in her amorous Bed,
Would spend the reuenues of the Crowne of France
Were it her owne: Ile temporize with her,
To effect some plot vpon my Soueraignes foes,
But shee shall know, Although shee loue me well,
My hearts desires were drownd with Floramell.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: By all descriptions this should be the man,
To whome I am directed by the Queene;
But whome doe I beholde the young Fytzwaters?

sp.speaker: Y. Fyth.
sp.l: Tis she, Oh no, shees in the Ocean drownd,
No; Shee escapt it seemes as well as I.
But I will take no acquaintance of my Loue,
Till shee has cleerd her from the Queenes suspect.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: It is not meete I take acquaintance first,
Nor will I till I know a iust cause why,
Of his Familiar dealings with the Queene,
Here is the key her Highnes promiz'd you.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.l: And you the prisoner to be safe lockt vp,
For your incontinence and wanton life.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: You doe me wrong, I hate incontinence,
Nor did I euer loue a wanton life:
I am a desolate Ladie, shipwrackt here,
And had a Husband once, too like thy lookes,
But not of such a rude condition.
Oh were hee present, and should heare thee speake
Such boystrous termes against his honourd wife,
He would out of the vertue of his minde
Knowing my conuersation to be good,
Write this base slander in thy villaines blood.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.l: So confident, her innocence is great,
That can doe this sincerely without trickes:
But if you be the same that you would seeme,
How comes that your reputations growne,
Into such scandall, and your name the theame,
Of euery idle fellow in the Court?
That Groomes report, faire Infortunate is:
The French Kings loue; Nay worse his concubine.
The voyce of men is held the voyce of God:
And where an euill is so farre proclaimde,
The generality approues the guilt,
And shees vnworthy to surviue a minute,
To be the separation of two hearts,
Made one by Marriage.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: Kill me, kill me then.
Hauing my sentence, wherfore am I sparde?
Or doe you take delight to torture mee?
Before you serue the Executione
The Law requires no more but death for Lust.
The lingring is a note of Tyrannie.
It is sufficient that the wretch must die,
The sooner done, the lesser crueltie.
But if your conscience vrge you to forbeare,
I shall confute your worthlesse Arguments,
And tell you in the purenesse of my soule,
Report's a lyar, common talke a Foole.
Wayters & Groomes, light-headed like theyr plumes,
And those that doe attend in Princes Courtes,
Too actiue and quicke-witted to depraue
A Courting they proclaime for a consent,
A fauour for the deede, belieue them not:
It is too common, this they hourely doe,
And thinke none chast, but her whom none did wooe,

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.l: But you did kisse the King.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: The Queene did see it,
Vrg'de by constraint, and Kingly violence.
Vpon condition hee should wooe no more:
And for that kisse I am esteemd a whore:
If you beleeue I am, I pray proceede,
I kist the King, doe you a murderous deede.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.l: Rise, rise, hereafter the discourse Ile tell,
Meane time Fytzwaters welcomes Floramell.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: So then I am honest by your owne confession,
But ere I entertaine you as a Husband,
Ile be resolu'd what Loue has past betweene
The Queene and you, that you her Agent are,
In such a weighty cause as is my life.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.l: Runs the stream this way, is the wind turnd thus?

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: I must know all.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.l: In sight of Heauen I vowe
Shee is as chaste for any lust from mee,
As vnborne Infants, and I vse her loue,
But to aduance my soueraigne and his Realme.
No other case by honour I protest,
In signe whereof I oppose an innocent breast
Against the sword: if you beleeue not, kill,
But neuer man died for a lesser ill.

sp.speaker: Floramel.
sp.l: I am satisfied, rise loue, and let vs goe,
Theres no true ioy without some taste of woe.

div.stage: Enter French King, Bastard, Saxon, Trier, and Mentz, Queene.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: Prosperity I thinke was borne in France,
Tis so obsequious vnto all our acts;
And like a subiect waites vpon our will:
To morrow is this happy enterview,
In which Fitz-waters and the Earle of Artoise,
Haue promisde to surprise the English King,
And the ambitious Palsgraue.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.l: If it take,
We shall haue cause to praise our happinesse.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: Take, out of all surmise: and in my thoughts
It is as good already as perform'de.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.l: I thinke no lesse.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: It is most probable.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.l: Where is the Queen she promisde vs a maske?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: The Palsgrave.

sp.speaker: F. K.
sp.l: Be Iouiall Caesar: mirth began the night:
And we will end it with the like delight.

div.stage: Enter King Edward, the Palsgraue and Y. Fitz, Floramell, Cullen, & diuers Lords in the Maske, they daunce there.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: We are beholding to you Gentlemen,
For this your Court-ship, pray discouer now.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: We will, and make you all die prisoners.

sp.speaker: F.K.
sp.l: King Edward heere?

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: The Palsgraue.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.l: All our foes.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Whose plot was this?

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.l: Or is it not a Dreame?

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.l: Tis such a Dreame youl neuer waken from?
To talke of this strange admiration,
Which like the night houers on euery eye:
Know that I haue deluded you with hopes
Vaine, like those villaines, which my sword did kill,
And by a Letter to the King deliuered,
Sent by your Queene, to be reueng'd for lust,
I causde his Maiestie to enter thus.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: I receiued them in at the backe Gate.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Wheres the Lady that has wrongd the Queen?

sp.speaker: Y. Fytzw:
sp.l: Heere is my trosh-plight wife,
Freer from that soule imputation,
Then is her Maiestie from iealousie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is shee then chaste?

sp.speaker: French King:
sp.l: Ile answere for the Virgin,
By my good Fortunes once, now by my beard,
She is as nobly vertuous of a stranger,
As ere I knew, and though I sought her loue,
I nere obtaind it.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: No, where is my witnesse?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sonne, call them in.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.l: What can you sweare?

sp.speaker: French:
sp.l: What must hee sweare?

sp.speaker: English:
sp.l: Ile sweare that the Lady is a good Ladie,
The Queen a good Queen, ther's an end of swearing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: English.
sp.p: And more then you should get of mee, but that the Queene gaue vs golde to say something: but who haue we here sirrah?

sp.speaker: Frenchm.
sp.p: Players, by this light players: Oh I loue a play with all my heart.

sp.speaker: English.
sp.l: Begin, begin, we are set.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.l: That's a braue King.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.l: Thats a braue boy that playes the Queenes part.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.l: He shalbe my Iuggler.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.l: And when the play's don, Ile be at charges
To bid them all to supper.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.l: Away with them.

sp.speaker: French:
sp.l: I am very sleepy.

sp.speaker: English:
sp.l: Would I were a bed,

sp.speaker: Y. Fitz.
sp.l: Ile leade you thither.

sp.speaker: English.
sp.l: God a mercy good Chamberlaine.

sp.speaker: French.
sp.p: The play's done, and now we must go home. Farewell. Exeunt Fooles.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: But shal the stream turne, this way is my plot
Become so weake? you will beleeue a Subiect
Before a Queene? I haue out-shot my selfe,
In seeking Iustice at an enemies hand:
This is a crosse beyond the strength of brayne;
Sure I shall end my dayes in Lunacy,
Like one to whom due vengeance is denide,
Because of weaknesse, on my selfe Ile turne
The fury that should light vpon my foe,
Scatter my hayre, like chaffe before the winde,
Hell in this world dwells in a iealous minde, Exit. Q.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: Our reuelling has strucke day out of night,
And bright Aurora vshers foorth the Sunne
To his diurnall course; yet neyther night,
Day, nor the morning, with her flaring beames,
Can stirre vp valour in this Saxons brest:
What, is thy minde made captiue with thy body?
Or thinkst thou that I take aduantages
Where honour should be shewd, Ime still my selfe
Ready to giue an answere to thy challenge
As at the first, and if thou conquerst me,
By my Atchiuements I will set thee free.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: You shew your selfe in this a Noble foe,
And I receiue more honour then I hop't:
I thought, because I was your prisoner,
You had esteemd captiuitie a conquest.
But since you haue awaked sleeping valour,
And giuen your Captiue such a priuiledge?
I am the same bolde combattant to dare,
And doe asmuch as erst I did intend.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.p: Choose your owne Weapons, and Ile meete you streight.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: My Armour there. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.l: Clinton and bold Fitzwaters are arriu'de,
And bring with them releast from seruitude
Brandenberg, Sauoy, and Bohemia.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Guide them in.

div.stage: Enter Old Fytzwaters, Clinton, Drum, and Cullens with Sauoy, Brandenberg, and Bishops, with Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Old Fytzw:
sp.p: Those with our selues, we humbly doe present vnto your Maiestie.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.p: Such as our Swordes by a glorious victorie set free.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: When Heauen is pleasde to giue prosperitie, How it flowes in: welcome my honord Friends: I am glad your thraldomes proue your libertie.

sp.speaker: Sauoy.
sp.l: The King of England has bene alwayes kinde.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: I haue euer found it so.

sp.speaker: Brandenb:
sp.l: And so haue I.

sp.speaker: Old Fytzw:
sp.p: Whom doe I fee? my Sonne that stole my Bride? As you respect my seruice (gracious King) Let me haue Iustice.

sp.speaker: Clint:
sp.l: Clinton kneeles with him.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.l: To their great seruice, greater I oppose,
And doe beseech your Highnes wrong me not.

sp.speaker: Old-Fyztw:
sp.l: Wrong thee?

sp.speaker: Y. Fytzw:
sp.p: I wrong mee, may not Kings doe wrong? Or dare you thinke because you are my Father, Ile loose my wife.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.l: Daughter come from him, least I force you hither.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: Father I may not.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.l: Fathers both shee shall not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Weele heare no more of these bold menaces
On paine of death I charge you both forbeare:
And let my censure sway this difference.
In England as your house the Byshop tolde mee
That Clintons Daughter by a precontract,
Was young Fytzwaters wife, and that some tricke
Betwixt the Fathers to preserue theyr wealth,
Broke off the match, to haue him wedde the olde.
This being true; I charge you on your liues
Vrge him no further in his lawfull choyce,
But as twas wrong enough to hinder it,
Make him amends, by being reconcilde,

sp.speaker: Y. Fytzw.
sp.l: Which I intreat vpon a dutious knee.

sp.speaker: Floramell.
sp.l: And so doe I.

sp.speaker: Old Fytzw.
sp.l: Rise, rise, I am frends with you both, and
When my Anger's ouer you shall find me a kind Father.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.l: So shall you.

sp.speaker: Y. Fytz.
sp.l: All lets are now remou'd, I am truly happy.

sp.speaker: Cullen.
sp.l: The Combattants are ready.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Guide them in.

div.stage: Enter seuerally Saxon and the Palsgraue Armd, and in theyr shyrts, Drum & Culiors.

sp.speaker: Palsgr.
sp.l: Idle are words where we must vse our swords,
Yet that it may appeare what mindes we beare,
Now we are marcht into this dreadfull Lists,
Know that this day my Honour shall exceede.
Or I lye breathlesse where I set my foote.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: Were thy brest Marble, & thy ribbs of brasse,
Saxon will haue the superioritie,
Or in this dreadfull place, his life expires.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.l: Sound trumpets, & the destinies guide all.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.l: The Palsgraue is invincible I thinke.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.l: Not to be ouercome.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Nor to be tam'de by any.

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: Matchlesse, and farre beyond the praise of words, are all thy actions, let me honour thee.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.l: Our Friends returnd in safety cheers more

sp.speaker: F. King.
sp.p: Caesar resigne your Title vnto Sauoy, and Sauoy, fit you vp, whilst the doctors heare ioyn all their hands to make thee Emperour.

sp.speaker: Palsgr:
sp.l: 〈◊〉 as the first.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.l: And to get your loue,
We will disgrace our selues to honour him.

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p: Receiue the Crowne, but as hee weares the same may it crush out his braines.

sp.speaker: Palsgr.
sp.l: Long liue and happily the 〈◊〉 Caesar.

sp.speaker: Sauoy.
sp.l: As happily as your kinded loues haue made me.
And long as please the Heauens.

sp.speaker: Palsgraue.
sp.l: Your fare●●● rights shall be perfect ●● with State in Germanie, whither I make the Maiestie of England, and all our Friends.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ile beare you companie.

sp.speaker: Palsgr:
sp.l: Faire windes and prosperous to our several
Realmes, wee wish and pray for, tis not our least good
To be the Fauorites of the waning Flood.
